posts.name: wyatt
posts.cooked:
Looking for some kind of system that could integrate into standard Frc can systems, preferably python based but I don’t care much, wanting it for a side project but don’t want to spend nearly 500 dollars on a Roborio 2, it would be used on some kind of turret bot on some kind of drive-base(not swerve)using likely the talon fx’s(new ones I think) and some spark maxes. need something I can use with can, less than $250us would be wonderful, thanks!

Side note: sorry if I’m missing some basic knowledge on some things here or if this seems low level, I am not a programmer but know some basic knowledge

posts.name: joemost
posts.cooked:
Someone might have a better idea, but I remember seeing on CTRE ’s website they support SocketCan. If you are trying to control all TalonFXs or TalonFXS’s this should be pretty doable.

RomiRobot was Raspberry Pi based, that might be a good reference point. Only thing is it isn’t using CAN . You could probably follow its model of PWM or do your own thing.

To get started with the Romi, you will need to have the necessary hardware. Romi Kit from Pololu – Order qualifies for free shipping, Raspberry Pi – 3B+ or 4, 8GB (or larger) Micro SD card, Micro S...

Hardware & Software Requirements Get started with the requirements to use Phoenix. These requirements highlight the supported devices, API targets, and SocketCAN adapters. Requirements Installing P...

Nice thing about this setup is there seems to be all sorts of people who have done things like this. A header to get CAN ability on the RaspberryPi is pretty cheap (under $20…)

Est. reading time: 10 minutes

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
stormsj28:

need something I can use with can,

Can you expound on this requirement?

Simply having a CAN bus available is not hard, but getting it to work with the FRC ecosystem of CAN -bus components is where the difficulty starts to ramp up.

Both of the motors you mentioned do allow for control (no sensor feedback) with PWM - would this suffice?

While this likely isn’t exactly what you were looking for, I spent some time getting some firmware up and going for an ESP32-based python solution that could do basic sensors and motor control, and allowed students to write programs from a web browser. It’s very similar to a Romi, just with a slightly different workflow.

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: Given how open the phoenix protocols are that’s where I would start, then rev cause there’s a surprising amount of their protocols available publicly

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
cmdada:

Given how open the phoenix protocols are that’s where I would start, t

This was something I actually didn’t know. For what it’s worth, I did a bit of googling and wasn’t able to find a specific page that documented all the messages and their meaning.

At a minimum, the heartbeat protocol is definitely not intended to be public, and would need some reverse engineering or disablement.

stormsj28:

I wasn’t sure it the talons could use pwm

Yup! See Bring Up: Talon FX/SRX and Victor SPX — Phoenix documentation - there’s a note in the box.

stormsj28:

With how Frc does can, is that t just more setup for a Roborio interface ig or like hardware client?

Today’s RIO CAN stack looks something like:

physical bus → transciever → CPU → NI’s Stack → WPILib and/or Vendor libraries → User code (ex: motor.getVelocity() )

There’s plenty of transceivers that work with cheaper CPU’s, so that’s not too hard to do. The part that’s still on the user is to emulate the NI/Wpilib/Vendor library functionality to get all the way back to useful data.

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: The heartbeat protocol is disabled when using ctre devices for non frc, there’s steps online for how to un-frc lock ctre hardware

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
Upside it was just part of the Lifeboat/framework gui tools. When you set a new non-roborio robot controller and flashed it with the image you then could also see connected Phoenix compatible devices and reset any sticky faults ( FRC locks).

I kept a hero board around as my firmware flasher which could lock and unlock from FRC mode and serve as a standalone CAN to USB hub. Then I’d connect the devices back to my Canable/Jetson Nano/Raspberry Pi with the Phoenix Framework running.

Both methods work, when doing it for 40+ motor controllers it was best to have the standalone device

posts.name: Cory
posts.cooked:
To summarize what a lot of other people said, at least for Talon FX’s, you have two options.

This requires a controller that supports standard “hobby style” PWM outputs (1-2ms rise-to-fall, 4-100ms rise-to-rise). This is generally going to be your cheapest solution, able to run on microcontrollers such as an Arduino, but will also be the most limiting as it’s output-only and simple duty cycle output.

We support Phoenix 6 using generic SocketCAN on Linux, as well as CANivore on Linux and Windows (exact requirements here ).

This means that you can take a Raspberry Pi, a CANable (or CANable clone) running candlelight firmware, and use our Phoenix 6 libraries to control devices, similar to if you were controlling them in FRC . The easiest route for this would probably be Python , but we do also support C++ . This also lets you connect to the Pi with Tuner and do remote debugging, diagnostics, setting ids, updating firmware, etc.

As always, if you have questions or run into issues, shoot an email to our support ( support@ctr-electronics.com ) and we’ll be more than happy to help!

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
I concur logic analyzers (with proper decoding) are a good way to reverse-engineer CAN bus communication.

Claims have been made above that the heartbeat can be turned off, and other parts of the protocol is documented already (though I’m not sure where). I’d posit any sort of reverse engineering is unnecessary.

posts.name: wyatt

TytanRock:

CANivore on Linux and Windows (exact requirements here ).

If I’m understanding this right I could run a raspberry pi and canivore and run that as a standard Frc control system style?

Second question: is there any true limit on how many devices the canivore can handle?

Third question: would I still be able to use all encoders in the motors(ex. Kraken encoders)

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
stormsj28:

If I’m understanding this right I could run a raspberry pi and canivore and run that as a standard Frc control system style?

Legally in competition no. The robot controller must be the RoboRio til 2027 then system core I believe takes over officially. For personal use, demo robots etc, yes it is functionally the same. Same Phoenix libraries but nothing like command based, timed robot etc. that’s all WPIlib.

I do not have a good answer for number 2, I own a CANivore but have not gotten to stress test it.

stormsj28:

Third question: would I still be able to use all encoders in the motors(ex. Kraken encoders)

Yes, you access these or the closed loop control modes through the API just like in your regular robot code. Below is a great example of the basics! This uses the TalonFX (motor controller for the Krakens).

GitHub - CrossTheRoadElec/Phoenix6-Linux-Example and the API here CTRE Phoenix 6 C++: ctre::phoenix6::hardware::core::CoreTalonFX Class Reference

posts.name: Cory
posts.cooked:
Mr. Siefen’s correct on both 1 and 3, so refer to his answers there.

The only thing I want to expand on is that while it’s not legal for a Raspberry Pi & CANivore to enable devices for FRC legality, a Raspberry Pi + CANivore can be used to control the actuators of the robot, so long as the enable signal is still coming from the roboRIO.

This means if you put a Raspberry Pi and CANivore on the same bus as a roboRIO and CANivore (or Pi and generic SocketCAN on the same bus as roboRIO’s native CAN ), the roboRIO will enable the devices, while control can be coming from the Pi. Some teams do this already in competition, so I want it to be clear that they’re not breaking any rules.

I also highly recommend looking at the non- FRC examples to see what a potential robot project architecture would look like.

But you can still reference the generic Phoenix6-Examples repo for specific feature examples, as we generally write examples so they can be pulled out of WPILib without a lot of hassle (exceptions being the Swerve, SysId, and CommandBased examples).

stormsj28:

Second question: is there any true limit on how many devices the canivore can handle?

The only “hard” limit is going to be your id space. Valid IDs range from 0 to 62 for any model, though you can have duplicate device IDs across different models (you can have a CANrange and Talon FX both be ID 5 for example).

What you’ll likely run into first is bandwidth limitations, every device added increases bus utilization by some amount based on the amount of data it sends out. We’ve stress tested the CANivore to 100% CAN FD utilization and proven everything is operational, but due to the nature of CAN you’ll start to get missed frames in this state. We recommend keeping utilization below 90% to avoid this.

You can choose to speed up or slow down data with the StatusSignal SetUpdateFrequency API, and by optimizing any data that’s not used . With default update rates, you should have about 45 Talon FXs before you start to run into issues on CANivore as a baseline.
